item.title: HIM, 2025 - ★★½
item.description:
i loved tyriq withers.
i did not love marlon wayans.
it was all MIDSOMMAR vibes and then i saw Music Composer BOBBY KRLIC in the credits and was like, "hell yeah"

it's flashy and looks good but the jokes never land and there's something that feels unimaginative about the vision of this film.

item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb

item.title: Puss in Boots: The Last Wish, 2022 - ★★★★½
item.letterboxd:filmTitle: Puss in Boots: The Last Wish
item.description:
I love movies but I love animation in particular — can you believe some people think it's a medium only suitable for children? I swear, someone must have zero imagination or media literacy to watch something like Puss in Boots: The Last Wish and conclude that only children are entertained by it.

In the latest podcast episode for JXN Film Club, I talked with my friend Morgan about our mutual love for the medium of animation. Check out our conversation here.
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb

item.title: Happy End, 1967 - ★★★★★
item.description:
trace back the histories from Tenet/Memento and Benjamin Button and this movie should pop up eventually. the storytelling from the reverse perspective is perfect dark comedy. 

absolutely fun -- and in ways i did not expect! so visually engaging and really a testament to the creativity of filmmakers and the craft across the century

watch this film for free on the Internet Archive

item.title: Shin Godzilla, 2016 - ★★★★★
item.description:
SICK

There's a needle drop of music from Evangelion and it got me PUMPED

I thought the production value was great and the evolution mechanics (and their analysis) were super fun. already mentioned one iconic needle drop, there are more. the plot really surprised me -- it was a political satire criticizing bureaucracy

watched with Andy and Ryan

item.title: JXNFC: Jake Sullivan’s Top 20
item.description:
• Cool Hand Luke

    A crash course in humanity. 

    "No man can eat 50 eggs."

  • The Godfather

    A crash course in film. Perfect in every aspect.

  • Blood Simple

    #3 is a revolving door of Coen films. This spot belongs to whichever I'm feeling the most on a given day. Their debut is underappreciated and seems like an appropriate placeholder.

  • Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid

    Every top 20 should have a western. And the best westerns are about bucking authority and beating the odds.

  • The Truman Show

    My life is definitely not filled by paid actors. But my brain thinks it might be.

  • Big Night

    The movie that taught me to appreciate food. And business. And Louie Prima.

    "Bite your teeth into the ass of life."

  • White Men Can't Jump

    Iconic 90s.

  • Thicker Than Water

    When I am wistful, surf docs settle my soul. This one is my go to.

  • Good Will Hunting

    Robin Williams at his very best and most vulnerable. RIP.

  • Attack the Block

    Pure fun. Easily my favorite monster movie.

...plus 10 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb

item.title: JXNFC: Jonathan Miles’ Top 20 Films
item.description:
Classics, action, comedy, fantasy. This list has a little of everything.

  1. The Big Lebowski

    The greatest film ever made, bar none. Shut the fuck up, Donny

  2. The Nice Guys

    Just two guys, in way over their heads.

  3. There Will Be Blood

    One of the greatest Method acting performances of all time, although my contention will ever be that Daniel Day-Lewis deserved his second Oscar before this for Gangs of New York.

  4. Hell or High Water

    The best Texas noir film since No Country For Old Men.

  5. Pride & Prejudice

    A stirringly scored, beautifully shot adaptation of the Austen novel.

  6. The Searchers

    A visually brilliant, brutally spectacular film, and the performance that should have won John Wayne his Academy Award, for bitter, racist ex-Confederate Ethan Edwards.

  7. Zodiac

    David Fincher’s masterpiece. A stacked cast and a case that was never solved.

  8. When Harry Met Sally...

    The ultimate rom-com

  9. Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby

    If you eat the DVD, it tastes like America

  10. Silver Linings Playbook

    Go Birds

...plus 10 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb

item.title: JXNFC: Quentin Jones' Top 20
item.description:
Quentin Jones, friend of the film club, listed his top 20 on the most recent episode of Jackson Film Club The Podcast.

Quentin found himself in Jackson after working on the film crew for the episode of We Are Here created in Jackson in 2022. His first and foremost reason for his residence in the city is the love of his life, Lydia. His second reason is his mission for cannabis awareness and advancement in the state's new medical marijuana program. His third reason is the great dance floor at Shade.

This top 20 list features epic American classics and some of the most innovative and groundbreaking cinema in the world. Tune in to our conversation wherever you get your podcasts.

Though this is presented as a ranked list, the films in positions 22 - 24 are honorable mentions and despicable artists-now-canceled.

  1. Get Out
  2. The Big Lebowski
  3. In the Mood for Love
  4. Hairspray
  5. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse
  6. Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse
  7. Blue Velvet
  8. Do the Right Thing
  9. Moonlight
  10. Barbie

...plus 14 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb

item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb

item.title: JXNFC - Animated Features
item.description:
This list was the basis of a special podcast episode. Check the link for more

https://jxnfilm.club/#animated-features

  • The Land Before Time

    Entered by Michael

    This film is my waypoint for consciousness -- I came to an understanding of death emotionally because of this movie. Nothing has ever quite hit the same, to be honest.

  • Rock-A-Doodle

    Entered by Michael

    When my parents would go to their weekly bowling league, I was the kid who would change the TV to Rock-A-Doodle at the childcare center next door.

  • One Hundred and One Dalmatians

    Entered by Michael

  • Princess Mononoke

    Entered by Michael

    This was when I realized that animation is for grownups, and that grownup stories can be told through animation. I love how this changed my imagination.

  • Spirited Away

    Entered by Michael

    I found this not far from the age of Chihiro. It means a lot to me because I moved twice before the age of 10 and this film teaches about life in its own way, through the eyes of a young person who has been Spirited Away.

  • Samurai Champloo

    Entered by Michael

    This anime popped up on Adult Swim, but I never finished the series on the air. Nearly 20 years later, I've finally watched the entirety and absolutely loved the ending.

  • The Hobbit

    Entered by Morgan

  • Heavy Metal

    Entered by Morgan

  • Waking Life

    Entered by Morgan

  • The Secret of Kells

    Entered by Morgan

...plus 1 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb

item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb

item.title: 2022 Goal: 100 New Directors
item.description:
I started the year with a pretty interesting ratio of 1.28:1 for number of films by a director. On 14 October 2021 I reached a milestone of 500 directors from 646 logged films, spanning 41 countries, inspiring my 2022 goal of watching 100 movies introducing myself to that many more new directors. As of completion of this goal, my ratio is 1.33 movies per director with over 700 directors logged. I look forward to seeing where it's at when I hit 1500 movies logged

tl;dr: for every movie on this list, 2022 is the first time I’ve seen something from that director.

  1. The Hand of God
  2. The Lost Daughter
  3. Summer of Soul (...Or, When the Revolution Could Not Be Televised)
  4. The Mask of Zorro
  5. The Paradise Next Door
  6. Lunch on the Grass
  7. Doctor Strange
  8. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
  9. A Bridge Too Far
  10. Encanto

...plus 89 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
